item.title: P02 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P02 Pronunciation Drills Video

Oct 10,2019

Resources

  • Audio/Video:

A video featuring 7 pronunciation drills from Premium episode 2. Repeat after me and pay attention to natural features of pronunciation like connected speech, sentence stress, weak forms and intonation. Also you can see my mouth and body moving while saying the sentences. Repeat, repeat, repeat! Practise, practise, practise!

Transcript:P02 Pronunciation Drills Video

What‚Äôs going on with these pronunciation videos? I said before that I‚Äôd do these regularly, using some sentences from the pronunciation drills from previous premium episodes.

I‚Äôve done P01, now it‚Äôs time for P02 and I‚Äôll keep adding these videos until I‚Äôve caught up with the audio episodes, then I‚Äôll be doing more videos for each new premium episode series as they are published. So that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre getting a video for episode 2 when I‚Äôm actually now publishing series 16, 17 and so on.

P02 Pronunciation Drills - from premium episode 2, which was my conversation with Raphael Miller from Liverpool.

I‚Äôve chosen these sentences because they‚Äôre not too long, contain things like phrasal verbs and other common bits of usage.

Also, having read out the sentences a few times I can tell they have a certain rhythm to them.

Look out for

  • Which words are stressed
  • How little words are pronounced with weak forms
  • How words are connected together
  • Listen to the pronunciation parts of recent premium episodes to find out more about word linking and weak forms.

As usual, try to say these without any pauses, unless a pause is necessary.

  • Have you tried turning it off and on again?
  • You don‚Äôt want to come across as fake
  • You‚Äôre setting up your own summer school
  • It gives them a chance to broaden their horizons a bit.
  • We don‚Äôt want students to be sitting around for hours.
  • Everyone‚Äôs in the same boat so you end up making friends
  • We‚Äôd always have a chat whenever we bumped into each other.

item.title: P03 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P03 Pronunciation Drills Video

Oct 28, 2019

video featuring pronunciation drills taken from Premium episode 03.

Transcript

Includes sample sentences from the pronunciation drills in premium episode 3, which was about the royal wedding with my mum (I mean my mum was in the episode, not in the wedding).

As usual, listen for which words are stressed in the sentence (usually the main ‚Äòmeaning‚Äô words) and how that affects the rest of the sentence, especially how other little words are pronounced using weak forms and how words are connected together in various ways.

Usually, auxiliary verbs in sentences are pronounced with weak forms, except in certain cases, like when they are at the end of the sentence, as you will hear in a couple of these examples.

  1. It was such a lovely day and her dress was so beautiful.
  2. The more I watched it, the more fascinated I became.
  3. A few years ago, I think I would have described myself as a republican.
  4. It was noticeable how nervous he was. (the first ‚Äòwas‚Äô is weak, the 2nd isn‚Äôt - because it‚Äôs at the end of the sentence)
  5. She could have been acting the whole thing. But I don‚Äôt think she was.
  6. Harry really seems to be taking it all in.
  7. He must have been thinking about her
  8. Can you imagine how tedious it must be?

item.title: P04 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P04 Pronunciation Drills Video

Dec 6, 2019

Pronunciation drills for premium episode 04, including target language from LEP#529 "The M Word" with Andy Johnson.

Episode Script and Drills

Hello premium people and welcome to the pronunciation drills video for P04. This is the 4th short pronunciation video that I‚Äôve done for you and it features pronunciation exercises using target language from episode 529 of Luke‚Äôs English Podcast (The M Word). Do you remember that episode? I chatted to friend of the podcast Andy Johnson about things like running marathons, giving talks about millennials and how he looks like Moby.

So there was episode 529, which was a conversation.

Premium episode 04 in which I broke down a lot of the language from the conversation.

And this video contains pronunciation drills featuring a selection of that vocabulary.

If you‚Äôre not sure what some of the language means, you‚Äôll have to go back to P04 and review it, either by listening or by checking the PDF.

In these drills we‚Äôre going to focus on all the usual things like sentence stress, connected speech and intonation. You just have to try and repeat them like me. You can see the sentences written on the screen. You should also try to repeat the sentences without reading them because it‚Äôs good training for your ears. So, consider using your finger or a piece of paper to just cover the sentences sometimes as you repeat. It‚Äôs good to practise repeating what you hear and then check the sentences to make sure you‚Äôre doing them properly. The sentences are also provided in the show notes.

Right, let‚Äôs go.

  1. I narrowly missed out on winning by just under 3 hours.
  2. This would have been Wednesday afternoon.
  3. As I was running down to meet him, I felt my calf muscle pop.
  4. You must have been gutted.
  5. We did a 90-minute run.
  6. I kept needing to stop to go to the toilet!
  7. I ran past a guy dressed as Jesus.
  8. There was a guy dressed as a toilet.

üéßüìñüó£

item.title: P05 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P05 Pronunciation Drills Video

Dec 7, 2019

Here are some pronunciation drills from P05 which was about language from 540 of LEP. That one was a ramble from me about things like the world cup, old computer games, getting music stuck in your head and more.

Just try to say the sentences like me. Copy my word stress, sentence stress, connected speech and other pronunciation features.

Listen and repeat.

  • Pause the video in order to repeat after me.
  • Check P05 again if you‚Äôre not sure of any vocab.

Pronunciation Drills

  1. This might be a trip down memory lane for some of you.
  2. If there are any new people listening to this - jump on board and get involved.
  3. They‚Äôre made of tough stuff (the Croatian team).
  4. I‚Äôve got a song running around my head and I can‚Äôt shift it.
  5. They were very catchy tunes indeed.
  6. Sonic the Hedgehog was popular ‚Äì but he couldn‚Äôt hold a candle to Mario and all the Mario games.

item.title: P06 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P06 Pronunciation Drills Video

Jun 23, 2020

Transcript

In this pronunciation drills video I‚Äôm going to do some pronunciation drills using language from Premium 06 focusing specifically on the section about verb forms. In P06 I dealt with vocab that came up in episodes I did about how I record episodes of the podcast. In this set of drills I‚Äôm focusing on the sentences containing verb phrases, especially from part 1 of the series.

Just try to repeat after me. Cover the screen there to avoid reading what you‚Äôre hearing. But use the notes to help you notice where the sentence stress is, and other details.

In terms of target language, it‚Äôs all about verb phrases, like these

  1. To go through something
  2. To build something up from scratch
  3. To build something up bit by bit
  4. To go straight over someone‚Äôs head
  5. To feel your way through
  6. To work it out as you go along
  7. To come up with ideas
  8. To turn them into content
  9. To write something down
  10. To break something down
  11. To set out to achieve something
  12. To dig deeper
  13. To lose track of time
  14. That‚Äôs 13 items of target language in 10 drills. To remember them all, go back to Premium series 6 and you can listen again to properly remember the context of these phrases and specifically what they mean.

For now, let‚Äôs look at how to say them in full sentences.

Focus on word stress in the sentence. The rest should fall into place when you get that right.

  1. You‚Äôll hear me going through all that language piece by piece.
  2. I built this business up from scratch.
  3. A lot of my advice just went straight over her head.
  4. I‚Äôm just feeling my way through the process and working it out as I go along.
  5. I‚Äôm going to talk about how to come up with ideas and then turn them into actual content.
  6. I have to write it all down or I won‚Äôt remember it.
  7. Let me break this down for you and make it simple.
  8. I can‚Äôt say I always achieve what I set out to achieve
  9. Always dig a little bit deeper.
  10. Sorry I must have lost track of time.

item.title: P07 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P07 Pronunciation Drills Video

Jun 24,2020

Transcript

This is a pronunciation drills video for P07 The Grammar of Gandalf. In this one we‚Äôre focusing on pronunciation for different verb tenses. If you remember, in series 07 I took a clip from the film version of Lord of the Rings and broke it down for grammar, covering a lot of verb tenses in the process. So this episode is going to deal with pronunciation drills across various verb tenses and for that reason it‚Äôs going to be really useful for you. Pay particular attention to the way auxiliary verbs are pronounced with weak forms and how words join together in connected speech.
Pronunciation Drills
  1. I am eager to get stuck in there.
  2. I have been painting this wall for 3 hours.
  3. I have drunk 3 coffees this morning.
  4. I have been meaning to reply to your email.
  5. Your podcast has helped me with my English.
  6. I visited Disneyland on 22 May 1992.
  7. I wish I hadn‚Äôt taken on this job.
  8. I do wish you would stop leaving the toilet seat up.
  9. I wish I could play guitar like Hendrix.
  10. I hope that you get the job.
  11. I wish I was a little bit taller.
  12. We were meant to be together.
  13. My package was delivered when I was out.

item.title: P07 [1/2] The Grammar of Gandalf - Verb Tense Review + more
item.description:
P07 [1/2] The Grammar of Gandalf - Verb Tense Review + more

Oct 10, 2018

Going deep into the grammar of English in this premium episode all about verb tenses. In this part we look at present perfect simple vs continuous, past simple for narratives, time expressions, and various other features of grammar.

The story context is about Lord of the Rings, but you don't need to be a fan to learn a lot from this episode.

Resources

  • PDF:p07-12-the-grammar-of-gandalf-verb-tense-review-more-computer-version.pdf
  • Audio/Video:

item.title: P07 [2/2] The Grammar of Gandalf - Verb Tense Review + more
item.description:
P07 [2/2] The Grammar of Gandalf - Verb Tense Review + more

Oct 12,2018

Continuing our in-depth look at the grammar of verb tenses, using a scene from Lord of the Rings as our sample of English.

This premium episode focuses on talking about the future, modal verbs, using wish, hope, pity, mean to correctly and how to avoid certain common mistakes. There are notes, scripts and 3 tests on the PDF. Answers for the tests and some pronunciation drills will be available in Part 3.

Resources

  • PDF:p07-22-the-grammar-of-gandalf-verb-tense-review-more-computer-version.pdf
  • Audio/Video:

item.description:
P07 [3] Pronunciation Drills - The Grammar of Gandalf - Verb Tense Review + More

Oct 12, 2018

This premium episode contains pronunciation drills focusing on the target language in parts 1 and 2.

Use the PDF to do the language tests, then listen to this episode and repeat the lines after me.

There are 3 tests available in the PDF, with answers. The pronunciation drills are based on the test answers.

Get the PDF in the app by clicking the gift icon. For this episode I recommend that you download the PDF from the website and print it in order to do the exercises with a pen in the old-fashioned way.

item.title: P08 Pronunciation Drills Video - FACIAL EXPRESSIONS & BODY LANGUAGE
item.description:
P08 Pronunciation Drills Video - FACIAL EXPRESSIONS & BODY LANGUAGE

Jun 25,2020

Hello, this is a pronunciation drills video for Premium series 8. This is a slightly longer one than usual, but it should be a good one.

I thought it would be funny and useful to record a video of myself saying the phrases from Premium episode 8 because body language and facial expressions are important. You don‚Äôt just say things with your mouth. You say them with your whole body.

For example,Check out this dialogue with no body language.
  • A: Hey, I‚Äôve got to tell you something. I‚Äôve met this girl and we‚Äôve fallen completely in love with each other. She actually makes me happy. You know what, I never realised I could be this happy. We‚Äôre going to get married and everything. This is fantastic! I‚Äôm absolutely delighted!
  • B: Wow, yeah, I bet you are mate, that‚Äôs amazing. Good for you. Nice one. Really happy for you mate!

OK, so with that kind of thing in mind, let‚Äôs go through the phrases from this series again. This time, you can see my body language. So think about my facial expressions, my attitude, the way I use my hands, the way I move my body.

I‚Äôm exaggerating a bit, for comic effect, but it‚Äôs a really good exercise for you to try to copy me too. See if you can say these phrases with attitude.

These are actually the phrases from the test in part 5 by the way.

Some Phrases from Parts 1 & 3

  • üóØOoh, there‚Äôs snow and ice outside and the thermometer says -15 degrees. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs probably coat-wearing weather,‚û°Ô∏è Yeah, no shit sherlock!
  • üóØImagine, you‚Äôre playing a game of cards and suddenly your friend gets serious and starts using some more competitive tactics. He‚Äôs suddenly become more ruthless. You notice the way his strategy has become more serious, so you say:‚û°Ô∏è Oh I see, (it‚Äôs) like that is it? We‚Äôre playing that kind of game, are we?
  • üóØYour friend says, ‚ÄúHey you‚Äôd better put your thick coat on, it‚Äôs absolutely freezing outside!‚Äù Then you get outside and it‚Äôs not as cold as you expected. ‚û°Ô∏è Come on, it‚Äôs not that cold.
  • üóØYou change out of your wet clothes into some warm pajamas and slippers. What do you say?‚û°Ô∏è Ahhhh, that‚Äôs more like it!
  • üóØYour friend says, ‚ÄúSo my boyfriend has promised that he‚Äôs going to stop drinking forever.‚Äù You don‚Äôt believe he will, and you think‚Ä¶ ‚û°Ô∏è Yeah, that‚Äôll be the day
  • Someone you know says, "Hey your English pronunciation is terrible! Ha ha ha!" (He pronounced the word ‚Äúpronunciation‚Äù wrong.)‚û°Ô∏è You can talk.
  • üóØYou‚Äôre a idiot.‚û°Ô∏è Well it takes one to know one!
  • üóØSo the guys from Orange say our internet won‚Äôt be connected until next week.‚û°Ô∏è Oh, you‚Äôve got to be kidding me!
  • üóØYou‚Äôve taken your kids to school and you want them to leave the car and enter the school‚û°Ô∏è Right, off you go then! See you later. Have a good day!
  • üóØYou see your friend who you haven‚Äôt seen for a while. You want to say ‚ÄúSo, how are you?‚Äù and you want to know about his/her recent activities. You‚Äôd like to catch up, basically.‚û°Ô∏è So, what have you been up to?

Phrases from Parts 2 & 4

  • üóØYou‚Äôre a teacher and you expect that your students haven‚Äôt done their homework again. You‚Äôre talking to your colleague. ‚û°Ô∏è I bet they haven‚Äôt done their homework again.
  • üóØYou ask your friend, ‚ÄúSo, how was the kids‚Äô party?‚Äù and she says"I tell you what, it was great but they were mental! 20 kids running around our house all day. I‚Äôm absolutely exhausted"‚û°Ô∏è Yeah, I bet you are!
  • üóØTwo friends are having a chat, and suddenly one of them makes a rude and suggestive innuendo (a suggestive joke)
  • Person A: ‚ÄúImagine living in the past when everyone rode around on horses.‚Äù Person B: ‚ÄúSounds quite nice to me‚Äù
  • Person A: ‚ÄúWhat, even the horses? It would be annoying, wouldn‚Äôt it?‚Äù
  • Person B: ‚ÄúOoh I don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôd quite like to have a hot muscular beast between my legs every day!‚Äù
  • ‚û°Ô∏è Oooh, I bet you would! Ha ha ha ha ha ha etc (immature giggling)
  • üóØShall we have lunch in the usual place?‚û°Ô∏è Yeah, we might as well.
  • üóØSo, Brexit has been called off. It‚Äôs not going to happen. A lot of people are pissed off about it, but on balance...‚û°Ô∏è ...It‚Äôs probably for the best.
  • üóØImagine, you‚Äôre in the pub with a friend who is in an excited and slightly crazy mood. He says ‚ÄúHey, let‚Äôs get the beers in, and we‚Äôll get shots too! Double shots for everyone!! Triple shots!!! Quadruple shots!!! Quint‚Ä¶ five shots for everyone!!‚Äù‚û°Ô∏è Alright, steady on! Easy tiger! Woah there!
  • üóØYou‚Äôre climbing on a chair to fix a lightbulb and my Mum is in the room. She‚Äôs suddenly worried that you‚Äôll have an accident. What does she say?‚û°Ô∏è Careful! (specific pronunciation)
  • 8. üóØSo you failed your driving test again. How do you feel?‚û°Ô∏è I‚Äôm absolutely gutted mate.

P08 [5/5] English phrases my wife has learned from me

Use this episode to test yourself. Can you say the right responses to my prompts? Can you repeat the phrases just like me, with the right intonation, stress and connected speech?

item.title: P09 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P09 Pronunciation Drills Video

Jun 26, 2020

Transcrip

Welcome to the pronunciation drills video for P09 which was all about language from the first Alan Partridge series I did (LEP 547-549).

These pronunciation drills videos are here to give you some extra practice with pronunciation, while also being able to watch me, watch my body language and the way my mouth moves.

As usual I do ask that you repeat after me. These videos are all part of a process of language practice to help you not just understand some target language but use it too.

Just repeat the sentences after me several times. Try to find the stressed words in the sentence. Watch out for weak forms of prepositions and auxiliary verbs and also the way words blend into each other with connected speech.

Honestly, this is how I understand you can improve your pronunciation and speaking, so I really hope you repeat after me rather than just watching me say some sentences.

You might want to check P09 again or possibly LEP 547-549 to hear all this language explained, demonstrated and presented in its original context.

  1. It requires really good English to be able to read between the lines and pick up on very slight verbal and non-verbal clues.
  2. Alan‚Äôs career is going badly. He‚Äôs drifted into obscurity.
  3. You go through a bad patch and you can smile at the end of it, probably.
  4. I didn‚Äôt say I was going through a bad patch, I said I was at a loose end.
  5. You both sound exhausted, have you been running?
  6. Do you fancy a breath of fresh air?
  7. I got caught in a taxi that broke down.
  8. I‚Äôd rather have a few superficial bruises than a massively lacerated face.
  9. I‚Äôd love to feel an airbag go off in my face.
  10. Come on Lynn, I‚Äôll drop you at a cab rank.

Video File

Este es.mp4

item.title: P09 [1/3] Language Review for LEP 547-549 British Comedy: Alan Partridge
item.description:
P09 [1/3] Language Review for LEP 547-549 British Comedy: Alan Partridge

Dec 20, 2018

A new premium series of all about language from the Alan Partridge episodes of LEP which I published in October.

This first part features analysis and teaching of various useful bits of English that were used in episodes 547, 548 & 549, including:
  • Describing character & personality - adjectives
  • Describing character & personality - nouns
  • Verb phrases
  • Prepositional phrases

In part 2 we will cover different aspects of English, including grammar and social English, all through the context of Alan Partridge. There will be the usual test and pronunciation drills in part 3. A-Haaaa!

Resources

  • PDF:p09-13-language-review-alan-partridge-computer-version.pdf
  • Audio/Video:

item.title: P09 [2/3] Language Review for LEP 547-549 British Comedy: Alan Partridge
item.description:
P09 [2/3] Language Review for LEP 547-549 British Comedy: Alan Partridge

Dec 20,2018

Part 2 of this series about language from the Alan Partridge episodes of LEP which I published in October.

This second part features analysis and teaching of various useful bits of English that were used in episodes 547, 548 & 549, including:

  1. A bit of grammar in the form of present perfect continuous
  2. Some social English, which means a few phrases or features of language that are quite common in social interactions, including some stuff on tag questions.
  3. Some bits of formal English. These are moments when Alan sounds a bit too formal. Let‚Äôs make his English sound more normal.
  4. Vocabulary relating to sex, childbirth and feelings, because Alan talks in one scene about the birth of his son Fernando, what happened and how he felt about it.
  5. Vocabulary relating to cars and driving + some other miscellaneous language

In part 3 there will be the usual test and pronunciation drills. A-Haaaa!

Resources

  • PDF:p09-23-language-review-alan-partrdige-computer-version.pdf
  • Audio/Video:

item.description:
P09 [3/3] Language Review for LEP 547-549 British Comedy: Alan Partridge

Part 3 of this new premium series all about language from the Alan Partridge episodes of LEP which I published in October.

In this part there's an audio test to help you remember the vocabulary and grammar from parts 1 & 2, and then some pronunciation drills to help you develop fluent and connected speech.

item.title: P10 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P10 Pronunciation Drills Video

Jun 27,2020

Transcript

Welcome to the pronunciation drills video for P10 which was the language analysis, test and pronunciation practice for language which came up in my conversation with Zdenek Lukas. Here you‚Äôll listen to and repeat phrases and sentences said by both of us.

The emphasis is on clear but fluent speech. As usual I recommend that you listen out for the sentence stress. There‚Äôs a lot of stress involved in learning English, isn‚Äôt there?

Sentence stress will guide you for other things like weak forms and connected speech so pay attention to that first.

  1. It can be a real pain in the neck, writing a masters degree.
  2. Some students left it until the last minute before doing their work.
  3. I studied economics at university but I just wasn‚Äôt cut out for it.
  4. I didn‚Äôt want to mess up or otherwise my boss would tell me off.
  5. There was a terrible drought in summer here.
  6. I have to make sure I get this right or they‚Äôre all going to take the piss out of me.
  7. Hopefully my daughter will grow up to be bilingual, which means she should have the advantage of speaking two languages.
  8. I put a lot of hard work into learning English and it‚Äôs really paying off for me now.
  9. Thank you for your offer, but I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôm going to turn it down.
  10. I haven't fixed the cupboard in the bathroom but I‚Äôll get round to it asap.

item.title: P11 Pronunciation Drills Video
item.description:
P11 Pronunciation Drills Video

Jun 29, 2020

In this one we‚Äôre going to practise saying 10 sentences that came up in Premium Episode 11, which was the analysis of language which came in the podcast episode I did about Paul Chowdhry.

NO PDF file

Transcript

Hello! Welcome to Premium Pronunciation Video number 11. In this one we‚Äôre going to practise saying 10 sentences that came up in Premium Episode 11, which was the analysis of language which came in the podcast episode I did about Paul Chowdhry.

That was a really full series of episodes absolutely jam packed with target language.

As usual with these pronunciation videos, I‚Äôve only taken a small selection of that target language for these drills. If you want all of it, including explanations and the rest, go back to P11 and listen to all of that. These drills come from the memory test & pron drills in the original series.

Focus on sentence stress, as usual. The rest should fall into place after that.

  • It‚Äôs boiling in here! I am absolutely boiling in this jacket!
  • I was absolutely roasting in bed last night. I‚Äôm not used to sleeping with the window closed.
  • We‚Äôre moving next month so we‚Äôre trying to get rid of as much of our stuff as possible.
  • My wife and I first moved in together when I moved out of my flat in London and moved to Paris.
  • I reckon it‚Äôll probably be cold outside today so you ought to bring a coat.
  • Could you put on a slight American accent for this job?
  • This cake is lovely. How did you make it so moist?
  • Sorry I had a bad day and I was just taking it out on you.
  • These towels still aren‚Äôt dry. They‚Äôre still a bit damp.
  • I‚Äôve got (a bit of) a bad stomach

item.title: P24 [Part 1] Homophones / Jokes (Vocab Builder, Spelling, Pronunciation)
item.description:
P24 [Part 1] Homophones / Jokes (Vocab Builder, Spelling, Pronunciation)

Sunday, Aug 2 2020

Homophones are words which sound exactly the same, but have different meanings different spellings. They cause lots of problems for learners of English, and are also the basics of lots of jokes in English. This series will help you deal with homophones and should help you build your vocabulary while improving your speling and pronunciation too.

item.description:

Friday,Sep 18 2020

Let's test your English and expand your vocabulary by going through a list of jokes all containing homophones (news o(new ones).

Finishing the series by giving you the usual memory tests and pronunciation drills to help you add more vocabulary to your active English.

item.description:
P25 Pronunciation Drills from LEP682 - Non-Standard English Accents vs RP

Oct 6,2020

As promised, here are 18 pronunciation drills to help you practise saying sentences in both RP and non-standard English (mainly London and Lancashire accents).

item.title: P26 Luke's Stand-Up Comedy Show (Live at The Comedy Store in London)
item.description:
P26 Luke's Stand-Up Comedy Show (Live at The Comedy Store in London)

Nov 9,2020

Here's a special gift for LEPe watch my introduction video (P26 Introduction) before you watch this.

I hope you enjoy the show!'s a special gift for LEP Premium subscribers. It's a video of me performing live stand up comedy on stage in London.

The video was filmed at The Comedy Store in London in November 2018, warming up the audience for Paul Taylor. Paul was making an episode of one of his TV shows and needed me to keep the audience entertained for 30 minutes before he arrived. The audience were mainly French people living in London, but also some Brits and people from other countries too.

Please watch my introduction video (P26 Introduction) before you watch this.

I hope you enjoy the show!

Here's a special gift for LEP Premium subscribers. It's a video of me performing live stand up comedy on stage in London.

NO PDF file

item.title: P27 [1/8] Error Correction from WISBOLEP - Grammar, Vocabulary & Pronunciation
item.description:
P27 [1/8] Error Correction from WISBOLEP - Grammar, Vocabulary & Pronunciation

Nov 26, 2020

Here's some remedial language practice (grammar & vocabulary) based on some errors I noticed in the WISBOLEP competition. Learn from some common errors and expand your English in the process. Part 1 of an 8-part series.

item.title: P27 [2/8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills P27 [2/8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills
item.description:
P27 [2/8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills

Nov 27,2020

Use the exercise on the PDF to help you remember target language from part 1 and use the pronunciation drills to practise clear and natural pronunciation. Includes a few random impressions of Christopher Walken and Paul McCartney.

item.description:
P27 [5/8] Error Correction - Grammar & Vocabulary

Using some common errors as a springboard for some grammar and vocabulary language practice. Pronunciation drills coming in part 6. Enjoy!

item.title: P27 [6/8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills P27 [6/8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills
item.description:
P27 [6/8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills

Jan. 29, 2021

More pronunciation practice to help you become more fluent and natural when you speak. I even wrote a motivational poem for this one, to encourage you to actually do the test and pronunciation exercises.

item.title: P27 [7/8] Error Correction - Pronunciation: Word stress, sentence stress & more
item.description:
P27 [7/8] Error Correction - Pronunciation: Word stress, sentence stress & more

Feb 16,2021

Word stress and sentence stress are perhaps the most important factors for producing clear speech. This episode gives you lots of practice, with plenty of listen & repeat drills.

item.title: P29 [Part 8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills (Featuring Rick Thompson himself)
item.description:
P29 [Part 8] Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills (Featuring Rick Thompson himself)

Jun 25, 2021

I have lost my voice because I have a cold, so I have asked my dad to record the pronunciation drills instead! Listen and repeat the sentences read out by Rick Thompson himself.

item.title: P29 [Part 7] What did Rick say? Vocabulary Review for LEP#704 (The Rick Thompson Report)
item.description:
P29 [Part 7] What did Rick say? Vocabulary Review for LEP#704 (The Rick Thompson Report)

Jun 20, 2021

Over 20 items of target language taken from a conversation with my dad about Brexit, with plenty of examples, collocations, exercises and discussion questions to help you fully understand this vocabulary and add it to your active vocabulary. This is the penultimate episode in the series.

item.title: P27 [8/8] A Premium Ramble: No pressure - let's just have a break!
item.description:
Join me for a 30(ish) minute ramble in which I talk about the importance of taking a break sometimes and not putting too much pressure on yourself.

There's no PDF for this episode. All you have to do is listen and follow what I'm saying üåû

item.description:
P28 [2/2] What did Lucy say? Memory Test & Pronunciation Drills

This is part 2 of the language review of my conversation with Lucy Earl. This one contains an exercise to help you remember and pronounce the phrases from part 1.

item.title: P29 [Part 1] What did Rick say? Vocabulary Review for LEP#704 The Rick Thompson Report
item.description:
P29 [Part 1] What did Rick say? Vocabulary Review for LEP#704 The Rick Thompson Report

Mar 20, 2021

Would you like to speak English like my Dad? Let‚Äôs look at some of the words and phrases he used in episode 704, see how they are used in context, understand them, remember them, practise using them and pronouncing them in sentences. This is the first part of a series of episodes.

item.title: P29 [Part 2] Memory Test / Listen & Repeat Pronunciation Drills
item.description:
P29 [Part 2] Memory Test / "Listen & Repeat" Pronunciation Drills

Mar 31, 2021

Practise your pronunciation by repeating these sentences after me, focusing on sentence stress, weak forms and connected speech. All the sentences use target language from P29 part 1.

item.description:
[Part 3] What did Rick say? Vocabulary Review for LEP#704 (The Rick Thompson Report)

More target language with vocabulary, collocations, synonyms, examples and speaking tasks covering extracts from the most recent conversation with my dad in episode 704.
